questions.question_text: An engineer must create a multicampus architecture wireless design to accommodate 4500 access points for wireless data and guest access. Which model controller fits the requirements to support all access points on one high availability controller setup?

choices.B: Both WLCs must have the same redundancy management IP address.
choices.C: Both WLCs must have the same service port IP address.
choices.E: The controllers must run the same operating system version.
choices.A: The controllers must have the same number of licenses.
choices.D: Each WLC must have a unique redundancy management IP address.

questions.question_text:
A wireless network consists of:
• two IOS XE controllers installed in a data center
• 9100 series APs
• corporate and a guest WLAN

The customer must high availability pair two Cisco WLCs for the client SSO. Which two design approaches must the engineer take to meet the requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
DE 

Both devices must run the same version of software.
Both devices must have redundant IPs in the same subnet. IP addresses used for redundancy must be unroutable without a gateway present in the subnet.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/catalyst-9800-series-wireless-controllers/213915-configure-catalyst-9800-wireless-control.html#toc-hId--1820882626

Selected Answer: DE
E is correct for SSO and only D says unique RMI ips, RMI IPs shoud be in same subnet , but should not be the same IP addresses

Selected Answer: D
The customer wants guest traffic to remain operational and the CAPWAP tunnel to stay up if one of the WLCs in the HA cluster fails.
In the HA SSO architecture in Catalyst 9800, the Mobility MAC address serves as a unique identifier for the entire cluster.
When the Active WLC fails, the Standby WLC immediately takes over without disrupting the CAPWAP tunnel to the Anchor WLC.
This single Mobility MAC address ensures that the Anchor WLC perceives the connection as unchanged, allowing the CAPWAP tunnel to remain intact without interruption.
Without Mobility MAC configuration, during the switchover to the Standby WLC, the CAPWAP tunnel would need to be re-established, potentially causing a temporary disruption in guest traffic.
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/9800/17-1/deployment-guide/c9800-ha-sso-deployment-guide-rel-17-1.pdf

Selected Answer: D
D.
Configuring the mobility MAC address ensures that the mobility group maintains a consistent identity, allowing seamless failover and continuity of anchored traffic.

choices.B: Deploy EMC APs as anchors and configure a high-availability cluster.
choices.C: Create a separate EoIP tunnel for each WLC in the high-availability cluster.
choices.A: Configure the APs with the high-availability cluster as the primary base.
choices.D: Configure the mobility MAC address for the high-availability cluster.

questions.question_text:
A customer has this wireless design:
• two Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series wireless controllers that are configured in a high-availability SSO cluster to manage the APs in a local office network
• 100 APs in local mode that are registered to the high-availability cluster
• one Catalyst 9800 Series wireless controller that is deployed as an anchor in a DMZ
• a CAPWAP tunnel in UP state between the high-availability cluster and the anchor WLC

The customer wants the anchored traffic to remain up if a single WLC in the high-availability cluster fails. How must this requirement be incorporated into the design?

choices.C: The tertiary controller is an HA-SKU controller, so it took priority.
choices.D: The tertiary controller is in the same subnet as the primary controller.
choices.A: The secondary controller was at capacity.
choices.B: The secondary controller is an SSO configuration.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I think the answer is A, because there is no automatic priority to an HA-SKU controller. If some AP landed on the tertiary controller, that has to be because the second one was at capacity.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer has identified that during a recent controller failure, several APs failed over to the tertiary controller instead of the secondary controller. The configuration from one of the APs is provided. Which design consideration led to the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Download Cisco Spectrum Expert, deploy a spare AP where you want to see the the live RF spectrum and put the AP into SE-Connect mode in Prime & let it reboot. Putty to controller, and do 'show ap config <ap-name>, take note of the RF Key string (note: this string appears to change on every reboot!), Run the Spectrum Expert client software and connect to the AP's IP Address using the current RF key. Marvel at being able to see microwave ovens wreck your 2.4GHz in real time then get kudos from your boss that you're doing Layer 1 survey without spending money on pricey airmagnet/ekahau equipment.

questions.question_text: During a post deployment site survey, issues are found with non-Wi-Fi interference. What should the engineer use to identify the source of the interference?
